results.title: ‘Ben Is Back,’ ‘Censor’ and More
results.abstract: Insightful dramas and unsettling horror make up this month’s collection of off-the-radar streaming gems.
des_facet: Making Waves: The Art of Cinematic Sound (Movie)

results.title: ‘Bodies Bodies Bodies’ and the Difficulty of Coping IRL
results.abstract: What happens when Gen Z loses Wi-Fi? Using horror and humor, the cast and filmmakers of the new slasher film aim for a generational portrait.

multimedia.caption: Amandla Stenberg (Sophie) and Maria Bakalova (Bee) in “Bodies Bodies Bodies,” a horror film about a group of stranded friends.

results.title: When Your Girlfriend Is Your Father
results.abstract: James Morosini, the writer-director and star of the catfishing comedy “I Love My Dad,” talks with his real father and Patton Oswalt, his onscreen father.

multimedia.caption: James Morosini, right, with Patton Oswalt in “I Love My Dad.”

results.title: Anne Heche Onscreen: Wily and Funny but Also Unnerving
results.abstract: Hollywood tried to slot her into cookie-cutter blockbusters, sometimes successfully. She was at her best playing competent women in extreme situations.
des_facet: I Know What You Did Last Summer (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Anne Heche in “Walking and Talking,” as the more together of two best friends.
Anne Heche in “Walking and Talking,” as the more together of two best friends.

results.abstract: This month’s picks include films about corrupt systems and a fun-loving superhero B movie.

results.title: John Boyega Won’t Let Go of ‘Star Wars’ or ‘Coming to America’
results.abstract: The star of “Breaking” talks about Fela Kuti, Hans Zimmer, Cha Cha Chicken and other sources of inspiration.

results.title: ‘Day Shift’ Review: Stakes Out
results.abstract: Jamie Foxx is a blue-collar vampire hunter and a steadying hand on the tiller of this frenzied action comedy.

results.title: A Swarm of 13-Year-Olds Took a Broadway Stage. What Could Go Wrong?
results.abstract: For the creators and cast of the 2008 musical “13,” a new Netflix adaptation brings back memories — theatrical and hormonal.

multimedia.caption: From left: Eamon Foley, Aaron Simon Gross, Graham Phillips, Delaney Moro and Brynn Williams in the musical “13,” which ran on Broadway in 2008.
From left: Eamon Foley, Aaron Simon Gross, Graham Phillips, Delaney Moro and Brynn Williams in the musical “13,” which ran on Broadway in 2008.
From left: Eamon Foley, Aaron Simon Gross, Graham Phillips, Delaney Moro and Brynn Williams in the musical “13,” which ran on Broadway in 2008.

results.title: ‘Inu-oh’ Review: Dazzling Anime Meets Medieval Epic
results.abstract: This modern riff on “The Tale of the Heike,” from 14th-century Japan, takes some confusing turns. But the animation is undeniably wonderful.

multimedia.caption: Masaaki Yuasa’s “Inu-oh” is often visually arresting, with washes of color and vivid characters.
Masaaki Yuasa’s “Inu-oh” is often visually arresting, with washes of color and vivid characters.
Masaaki Yuasa’s “Inu-oh” is often visually arresting, with washes of color and vivid characters.

results.title: ‘Daisies’: Two Wild and Crazy Gals
results.abstract: The Czechoslovak New Wave film “Daisies” features an insolent pair of young girls determined to be as “spoiled” as the world.

multimedia.caption: Ivana Karbanova, left, and Jitka Cerhova as the mischief-making Marie and Marie in the 1967 film “Daisies,” directed by Vera Chytilova.
Ivana Karbanova, left, and Jitka Cerhova as the mischief-making Marie and Marie in the 1967 film “Daisies,” directed by Vera Chytilova.
Ivana Karbanova, left, and Jitka Cerhova as the mischief-making Marie and Marie in the 1967 film “Daisies,” directed by Vera Chytilova.

results.title: ‘Look Both Ways’ Review: To Be and Not to Be
results.abstract: This Netflix drama stages a delusion of young womanhood by tracking its heroine down forking paths: one in which she gets pregnant, and one in which she pursues a career.

multimedia.caption: Lili Reinhart in “Look Both Ways.”
Lili Reinhart in “Look Both Ways.”
Lili Reinhart in “Look Both Ways.”

results.title: Wolfgang Petersen, Director of ‘Das Boot,’ Is Dead at 81
results.abstract: He made it big in Hollywood with box-office hits, but he’s best remembered for a harrowing, Oscar-nominated German film set inside a U-boat in World War II.

multimedia.caption: Wolfgang Petersen in 2000. In a long career, he toggled between his native Germany, where he was part of the New German Cinema, and Hollywood, where he became a master of genre films.
Wolfgang Petersen in 2000. In a long career, he toggled between his native Germany, where he was part of the New German Cinema, and Hollywood, where he became a master of genre films.
Wolfgang Petersen in 2000. In a long career, he toggled between his native Germany, where he was part of the New German Cinema, and Hollywood, where he became a master of genre films.

results.title: ‘Le Temps Perdu’ Review: Proust Club
results.abstract: This cozy documentary sits in with a group of older readers in Buenos Aires who gather at a cafe to savor Proust’s “In Search of Lost Time.”

multimedia.caption: A group gathers to discuss Proust’s “In Search of Lost Time” in the documentary “Le Temps Perdu.”
A group gathers to discuss Proust’s “In Search of Lost Time” in the documentary “Le Temps Perdu.”
A group gathers to discuss Proust’s “In Search of Lost Time” in the documentary “Le Temps Perdu.”

results.title: An Oscars Apology for Sacheen Littlefeather, 50 Years After Brando Protest
results.abstract: The Apache activist and actress was booed onstage in 1973 after she refused the best actor award on Marlon Brando’s behalf and criticized Hollywood for its depictions of Native Americans.
org_facet: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

multimedia.caption: Sacheen Littlefeather was booed and cheered after she explained that she was representing Marlon Brando and that he could not accept the award because of “the treatment of American Indians today by the film industry.”

Sacheen Littlefeather was booed and cheered after she explained that she was representing Marlon Brando and that he could not accept the award because of “the treatment of American Indians today by the film industry.”

Sacheen Littlefeather was booed and cheered after she explained that she was representing Marlon Brando and that he could not accept the award because of “the treatment of American Indians today by the film industry.”

results.title: National Endowment for the Humanities Announces $31.5 Million in Grants
results.abstract: The third round of funding for the year will support 226 projects across the country.

results.title: Nicholas Evans, Author of ‘The Horse Whisperer,’ Dies at 72
results.abstract: He was a first-time novelist whose tale of a manly vocation and family trauma broke publishing and then movie rights records when Robert Redford bought them.

multimedia.caption: Nicholas Evans in 2005. Critics were scathing about his first novel, “The Horse Whisperer,” but he received more favorable reviews with his next three books.
Nicholas Evans in 2005. Critics were scathing about his first novel, “The Horse Whisperer,” but he received more favorable reviews with his next three books.

results.title: You Are Getting Sleepy. When You Wake Up, You Will Be an Improv Star.
results.abstract: In “Hyprov,” audience members are hypnotized into performing sketches. The show’s creators argue that the novices make stronger choices than pros would.

multimedia.caption: Volunteers undergoing hypnosis onstage at “Hyprov.” The show is the brainchild of Asad Mecci and Colin Mochrie.
multimedia.copyright: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times

results.title: Anne Heche, Actress Known for ’90s Film Roles, Dies at 53
results.abstract: Ms. Heche, who won a Daytime Emmy early in her career and whose films included “Donnie Brasco” and “Wag the Dog,” had been critically injured in a car crash.

multimedia.caption: The actress Anne Heche at the Directors Guild of America Awards in Beverly Hills, Calif., in March.
The actress Anne Heche at the Directors Guild of America Awards in Beverly Hills, Calif., in March.
The actress Anne Heche at the Directors Guild of America Awards in Beverly Hills, Calif., in March.

results.title: The Composer Who Turns Hayao Miyazaki’s Humane Touch Into Music
results.abstract: Joe Hisaishi’s scores have helped make Studio Ghibli films indelible. But in concert, the works stand on their own. That’s because “it’s about emotion,” he says.
des_facet: Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind (Movie)

multimedia.caption: “Watching a film is a whole different thing from hearing the music in concert, which gives the audience a different experience,” Joe Hisaishi said.
“Watching a film is a whole different thing from hearing the music in concert, which gives the audience a different experience,” Joe Hisaishi said.
“Watching a film is a whole different thing from hearing the music in concert, which gives the audience a different experience,” Joe Hisaishi said.

results.title: Anne Heche Is Brain-Dead After Crash, Representative Says
results.abstract: The actress, 53, was being kept on life support while it was being determined if her organs could be donated, the representative said.
results.byline: By Daniel Victor and Remy Tumin

multimedia.caption: Anne Heche starred in several popular Hollywood films in the late 1990s, including “Donnie Brasco,” “Wag the Dog” and “Six Days Seven Nights.”

results.title: Roger E. Mosley, Actor Best Known for ‘Magnum, P.I.,’ Dies at 83
results.abstract: He played Leadbelly and Sonny Liston on the big screen. But his most high-profile role was a rugged, wry Vietnam War veteran opposite Tom Selleck on TV.

multimedia.caption: Roger E. Mosley in an episode of the TV series “Magnum, P.I.” as the helicopter pilot T.C., his best-known role.

results.title: Frank Miller Sues Widow of Comics Magazine Editor for the Return of Artworks
results.abstract: Two of Miller’s original drawings that were used in 1980s issues of David Anthony Kraft’s magazine Comics Interview were gifts, Kraft’s wife says. Miller says they were not.

multimedia.caption: Frank Miller is suing for the return of this artwork, here on the paste-up for a Comics Interview cover, which features an early depiction of Batman and a Robin, Carrie Kelley, from The Dark Knight Returns.

Frank Miller is suing for the return of this artwork, here on the paste-up for a Comics Interview cover, which features an early depiction of Batman and a Robin, Carrie Kelley, from The Dark Knight Returns.

results.abstract: Activists helped free a Korean immigrant, and this documentary explores the wrongful conviction and its ripple effect.

results.title: ‘Stay on Board: The Leo Baker Story’ Review: Surviving the Grind
results.abstract: In this documentary, a professional skateboarder turns down the Olympics for the chance to live openly.
